Banded iron formations (BIFs) are distinctive sedimentary rock units composed of alternating layers of iron-rich minerals and iron-poor silica-rich bands, typically red due to hematite. These formations provide critical evidence of early biological and geochemical processes.\nThe prevailing hypothesis suggests that BIFs formed in ancient oceans as a result of oxygen released by photosynthetic cyanobacteria. Their presence in the Early Archean suggests that life may have existed as early as 3.85 billion years ago.\nDuring this period, Earth\'s oceans contained vast amounts of dissolved iron. As photosynthetic organisms produced oxygen, the iron reacted with it, precipitating as iron oxides and accumulating in these layered deposits. BIFs are rare in younger geological periods because most of the dissolved iron in the oceans was eventually removed, marking the Great Oxidation Event around 2.4 billion years ago.

Stromatolites are layered, accretionary structures formed in shallow water through the trapping, binding, and cementation of sedimentary grains by microbial mats, primarily composed of cyanobacteria.\Fossilized stromatolites provide some of the oldest direct evidence of life on Earth, with examples dating back over 3.45 billion years. They exhibit a variety of forms and structures, ranging from columnar to domal shapes. While stromatolites are typically associated with biological activity, some possess features consistent with abiotic precipitation, making their origin a subject of ongoing study.\nStromatolites reached their peak diversity around 1.25 billion years ago, after which they declined in abundance and morphological variety, likely due to the rise of grazing organisms. Today, modern stromatolites are rare and primarily found in extreme environments such as hypersaline lakes and marine lagoons, where high salinity deters most grazing animals.

Primaevifilum amoenum is one of the oldest known bacteria, with fossilized remains discovered in Western Australia. It was a filamentous microorganism that primarily lived in individual clasts, though it may have been part of a loosely organized benthic microbial community embedded in mucilage.\nUnlike many early microbial fossils, its microfossils have not been detected in stromatolite-like laminated clasts, suggesting a different ecological niche. These findings contribute to our understanding of early microbial diversity and the environmental conditions of the Archean Earth.

Acritarchs are small, organic-walled microfossils that are resistant to acid dissolution and remain taxonomically unclassified. They represent a diverse group of structures, including the resting cysts of various green algae and possibly other microorganisms. Some acritarchs may also be linked to the reproductive or protective stages of unknown ancient eukaryotic life forms.\nDue to their resilience and abundance in the fossil record, acritarchs serve as valuable biostratigraphic markers, helping scientists understand the evolution of early life and past environmental conditions.

Bangiomorpha pubescens is the earliest known sexually reproducing organism, dating to approximately 1.2 billion years ago. It belongs to the red algae (Rhodophyta) and is considered one of the first complex multicellular eukaryotes. The emergence of sexual reproduction was a pivotal moment in evolutionary history, not only because of the benefits of genetic recombination but also because it enabled the development of complex multicellularity. This evolutionary breakthrough laid the foundation for the diversification of eukaryotic life, making Bangiomorpha a crucial organism in the history of life on Earth.

Nemiana simplex is one of the simplest sessile organisms of the Ediacaran biota, resembling a cnidarian-like jellyfish or a basal, soft-bodied polyp. It consists of a jelly-like sac that likely housed internal structures, though its anatomy remains poorly understood. Some hypotheses suggest it may have possessed small tentacle-like structures.\nIt is possible that this organism was entirely immobile, adhering to the seafloor, and fed through passive suspension feeding or direct absorption of dissolved nutrients from the water, possibly relying on microbial or algal matter for sustenance.

Tribrachidium heraldicum was a tri-radially symmetrical organism that lived during the Late Ediacaran Period of the Proterozoic Eon, approximately 555 million years ago. It was a soft-bodied, benthic organism that likely rested on or was temporarily attached to the seafloor.\nUnlike most modern animals, Tribrachidium does not fit into any known major animal group, and its exact classification remains uncertain. It likely fed using a unique form of suspension feeding, generating microcurrents to capture organic particles suspended in the water.

Dickinsonia is one of the earliest known organisms exhibiting bilateral symmetry, a body plan that later became dominant among modern animals. Its growth was likely indeterminate, as fossil specimens range from a few millimeters to approximately 1.4 meters in length. Evidence suggests that Dickinsonia grew continuously until it was buried by ocean sediments or otherwise perished.\nUnlike true bilaterians, Dickinsonia lacked a rigid body structure and may have absorbed nutrients directly from microbial mats on the seafloor. It spent most, if not all, of its life with its body in close contact with the sediment, possibly anchoring itself partially to the substrate.

Cloudinids are among the earliest known animals with mineralized skeletons, dating to the late Ediacaran Period, approximately 550–541 million years ago. Their fossils consist of millimeter-scale calcareous cones nested within one another, forming tube-like structures. The emergence of mineralized skeletons may indicate the evolution of more complex ecological interactions by the end of the Proterozoic Eon.\nUntil this time, most organisms were benthic filter feeders, but fossil evidence from the late Proterozoic suggests the first appearance of predators. The presence of boreholes in Cloudina fossils provides some of the earliest direct evidence of predation, marking a significant shift in the evolution of marine ecosystems.

Charnia is a highly significant fossil, as it was the first Precambrian organism to be formally described from undoubted Precambrian rocks. It is also thought to be among the earliest known animals capable of sexual reproduction. Although its frond-like appearance resembles that of a fern, Charnia was neither a plant nor an algae, as it lived in deep-water environments well below the photic zone, where photosynthesis is impossible.\nInstead, it is believed to have absorbed nutrients directly from the surrounding water, possibly through osmotrophy, a feeding strategy common among some modern marine organisms.

Treptichnus pedum is a crucial trace fossil because it marks the first known burrowing behavior, helping to define the boundary between the Ediacaran and Cambrian periods.\nSince only its burrows have been found, scientists infer that the organism responsible for Treptichnus pedum lacked hard anatomical features such as shells or bones. It is likely related to modern priapulid worms, which also exhibit similar burrowing behaviors.

Conodonta were ancient, eel-like, jawless vertebrates whose fossilized elements serve as crucial index fossils for stratigraphic correlation. Although these tooth-like elements appear formidable, the animals themselves were likely not active predators, possibly due to the lateral placement of their eyes. Estimates suggest that conodonts ranged in body length from 1 to 40 cm, highlighting the diversity among these early chordates.

Archaeocyatha were the first large skeletal animals and the earliest known reef builders of the Cambrian, thriving in warm tropical and subtropical waters. Some archaeocyaths lived as solitary organisms, while others formed colonies, contributing to the structure of early marine ecosystems.\nThey resembled hollow horn corals, with porous, cup-shaped skeletons composed of calcite, which allowed water to circulate through their bodies for filter feeding.\nAround 516 million years ago, archaeocyaths experienced a sharp decline, coinciding with the rapid diversification of demosponges, which may have competed for ecological niches.

Trilobites represent one of the earliest known groups of arthropods and are iconic examples of Cambrian marine life. They flourished throughout the Paleozoic Era but experienced a significant decline during the Devonian before going extinct at the end of the Permian.\nTrilobites were among the most successful early animals, thriving in the oceans for over 270 million years. They exhibited a wide range of lifestyles—some crawled along the seafloor as predators, scavengers, or filter feeders, while others swam through the water column, feeding on plankton.\nIf you ever visit Morocco, you will likely encounter many merchants selling trilobite fossils, as the Anti-Atlas Mountains are composed of Paleozoic rocks rich in these ancient arthropods.

Wiwaxia is a genus of soft-bodied, bottom-dwelling animals covered in rows of carbonaceous scales and long, sharp spines. These dorsal spines may have served as a defense mechanism against predators. Wiwaxia likely moved by contracting a slug-like foot on its underside, similar to modern mollusks.

Myllokunmingia is a genus of basal chordates, measuring approximately 28 mm in length and 6 mm in height. It is one of the oldest known possible craniates, possessing a skull and skeletal structures made of cartilage. Its anatomy suggests it was an early step in vertebrate evolution, sharing characteristics with modern jawless fish.

Pikaia is one of the oldest known relatives of vertebrates, exhibiting a worm-like body and likely swimming in an eel-like manner. Fossils reveal key chordate features, including an elongated notochord, a dorsal nerve cord, and segmented myotomes—critical characteristics in the early evolution of vertebrates.

Anomalocaris was a marine predator closely related to ancestral arthropods. It was one of the largest animals of the Cambrian oceans, reaching up to a meter in length. It possessed highly sophisticated stalked eyes, each with at least 16,000 lenses, providing vision as acute as that of modern insects. Its circular mouth was lined with a ring of hardened plates, adapted for grasping and consuming prey.

Opabinia was a soft-bodied marine animal of modest size, measuring between 4 and 7 cm in length. Its segmented body featured lateral lobes for swimming and a fan-shaped tail for propulsion. The head had highly unusual characteristics, including five eyes, a downward-facing mouth positioned beneath the head, and a flexible proboscis likely used to grasp and transfer food to the mouth.\nOpabinia likely lived on the seafloor, using its proboscis to search for and capture small, soft-bodied prey.

Marrella was a small arthropod from the Middle Cambrian, measuring up to 2 cm in length. It scavenged organic debris along the seafloor. Marrella is considered a stem-group arthropod, meaning it shares a common ancestor with most or all later major arthropod groups but does not belong to any modern lineage.\nDespite its superficial resemblance to trilobites, Marrella is not more closely related to them than to other arthropods.

Foraminifera are a group of amoeboid protists characterized by a streaming granular ectoplasm, which they use for capturing food and interacting with their environment. They are commonly encased in an external shell, or test, composed of various materials and exhibiting diverse forms. Most foraminifera are marine, with only a few species known from freshwater habitats.\nTheir shells are typically made of calcium carbonate and are usually less than 1 mm in size, though some species can grow up to 20 cm. Foraminifera are widely used as index fossils, particularly for dating rock layers from the Permian, Jurassic, Cretaceous, and Cenozoic periods.

Hallucigenia is thought to be an early relative of modern velvet worms (onychophorans), though some researchers suggest a closer relationship to arthropods. Its quirky name reflects its unusual appearance and the eccentric history of its study. This small, tubular organism measured between 0.5 and 3.5 cm in length and had seven or eight pairs of slender legs, each ending in a pair of claws. Additionally, it possessed spiny dorsal projections, likely serving as a defense against predators.

Orthoceras is a genus of extinct nautiloid cephalopods characterized by their long, straight, conical shells. These ancient marine animals lived during the Ordovician period and were among the earliest cephalopods. Based on their anatomy and the behavior of their modern relatives—squid, octopuses, cuttlefish, and the nautilus—it is likely that Orthoceras was a predator in the Paleozoic seas, hunting smaller marine creatures such as trilobites. Their streamlined shells allowed them to move through the water using jet propulsion, similar to modern cephalopods.

Pentecopterus decorahensis is the oldest known eurypterid, or "sea scorpion," dating back to the early Ordovician period. It could reach lengths of up to 1.83 meters, making it not only the earliest but also one of the largest arthropods ever discovered.\nSea scorpions were formidable marine predators that dominated coastal environments for millions of years, until their extinction during the Permian mass extinction event. They are closely related to modern horseshoe crabs—an ancient group of arthropods that still exists today.

Sacabambaspis is a jawless fish and one of the earliest known vertebrates to possess skeletal tissues similar to those of modern vertebrates. It lived during the Ordovician period and had a distinctive armored head shield. Sacabambaspis also featured a primitive lateral line system—an early sensory structure still found in modern fish—that allowed it to detect vibrations and movement in the water.

Astraspis is one of the oldest known armored jawless fish, dating back to the Ordovician period. Its body was protected by large bony plates on the head and smaller, scale-like plates covering the rest of the body. It also had a mobile, flexible tail that aided in swimming, covered with small protective plate-like scales. Astraspis is significant in early vertebrate evolution as it shows the development of dermal armor, a key adaptation for defense in prehistoric seas.

Rugosa is an extinct order of corals that lived from the Middle Ordovician to the Late Permian. They existed in both solitary and colonial forms. Solitary individuals are commonly called horn corals due to their distinctive horn-shaped skeletons. Their hard skeletons were composed of calcite, which contributed to fossil preservation. Rugose corals played an important role in reef ecosystems before going extinct during the Permian mass extinction, also known as the Great Dying.

Tabulata is an extinct order of colonial corals that lived from the Early Ordovician to the end of the Permian period, coexisting with Rugosa. Their tightly packed, tube-like coral structures gave them a honeycomb-like appearance. Like Rugosa, their skeletons were composed of calcite, which helped preserve them as fossils. Tabulate corals were major reef builders in Paleozoic seas and played an important role in forming ancient marine ecosystems. They went extinct during the Permian mass extinction, the most severe extinction event in Earth\'s history.

Eurypterus is an extinct genus of sea scorpions (eurypterids), and its fossils are among the most commonly found within this group. These ancient arthropods were both predators and scavengers, capable of growing up to 1.3 meters in length. While primarily aquatic, they possessed the ability to breathe air and walk on land for brief periods, possibly to move between water bodies or escape unfavorable conditions.

Pneumodesmus is the earliest known myriapod and the oldest documented creature to have lived on land. It is also the first arthropod discovered with a tracheal system, making it the earliest known oxygen-breathing animal on land. Its fossil, found in Scotland, dates back to approximately 428 million years ago, providing significant insights into the early colonization of terrestrial environments.

Cooksonia is an extinct group of primitive land plants, representing some of the earliest vascular plants. They include the oldest known plant to possess a stem with vascular tissue, which allowed efficient water and nutrient transport. Cooksonia lacked leaves, flowers, and roots, and they were typically small, standing only a few centimeters tall. Each branch terminated in a sporangium, a spore-bearing capsule, which played a crucial role in their reproduction.

Baragwanathia is a genus of extinct Lycopodiophyta plants, considered one of the earliest known vascular plants. They had unbranched, strap-shaped microphylls (small, simple leaves), and their stems contained an actinostele, a primitive type of vascular bundle arranged in a star-like pattern. These features indicate that Baragwanathia was an early representative of clubmoss-like plants, which would later diversify significantly.

Acanthodians, sometimes called spiny sharks, are an extinct group of fish that shared characteristics with both bony (Osteichthyes) and cartilaginous fish (Chondrichthyes). Despite their common name, they are not true sharks but represent several independent phylogenetic branches of early jawed fish. Acanthodians are considered ancestors to modern cartilaginous fish, such as sharks and chimaeras, and are significant for being among the first vertebrates to develop jaws, a major evolutionary advancement.

Entelognathus is an ancient placoderm fish and represents one of the earliest known jawed vertebrates. It is the first fish to possess dermal marginal jaw bones, including the premaxilla, maxilla, and dentary, which are typically found in modern bony fish. This discovery provides important evidence of the evolutionary transition from armored jawless fish to jawed vertebrates.

Prototaxites is a genus of ancient organisms that formed large trunk-like structures, up to 1 meter wide and reaching heights of up to 8 meters. Although it first appeared in the Late Silurian period, it reached its greatest diversity during the Devonian. Initially believed to be a giant fungus, recent discoveries indicate the presence of algal symbionts, suggesting that Prototaxites was more likely a lichen rather than a fungus in the strict sense.\nPrototaxites became extinct as shrubs and vascular trees rose to dominance, gradually replacing these massive structures in terrestrial ecosystems.

Wattieza is a genus of prehistoric trees, considered to be the oldest known trees on Earth. They existed during the Middle Devonian period and were closely related to modern ferns and horsetails. Wattieza trees could grow up to 8 meters or more in height and reproduced by releasing spores, much like their modern relatives.

Archaeopteris is an extinct genus of tree-like plants characterized by fern-like leaves. These plants could grow up to 10 meters in height, with trunks exceeding 1.5 meters in diameter. Archaeopteris thrived in wet soils, typically growing near river systems and within floodplain woodlands. It is considered a distant ancestor of modern gymnosperm plants, such as conifers, and played a significant role in forming some of the earliest forest ecosystems on Earth.

Although it resembles an amphibian, Tiktaalik is a lobe-finned fish from the Late Devonian period, possessing many features similar to those of tetrapods. Tiktaalik is considered a key representative of the evolutionary transition from fish to amphibians. It exemplifies one of several ancient sarcopterygian fish lineages that developed adaptations for surviving in oxygen-poor, shallow-water habitats—environmental conditions that are believed to have driven the evolution of tetrapods.\nIt is thought that Tiktaalik was specialized for living in swampy, pond-like environments and may have occasionally used its uniquely adapted fins to move short distances over land.

Ichthyostega is one of the earliest known tetrapods in the fossil record, living at the end of the Devonian period. It possessed lungs and limbs, adaptations that allowed it to navigate through shallow swamp waters. Although it resembles an amphibian, Ichthyostega is considered a stem group tetrapod and one of the closest known ancestors of modern amphibians. It had a fish-like tail and gills, but also possessed an amphibian-like skull and robust limbs, reflecting its transitional status between aquatic and terrestrial life.

Bothriolepis is a widespread, abundant, and diverse genus of placoderms that thrived during the Middle to Late Devonian period. The largest species could reach about 1 meter in length. Bothriolepis was a bottom-dwelling, armored fish that primarily fed on detritus, algae, and small microorganisms, using its specialized mouthparts to sift through sediment.

Cladoselache is one of the earliest known shark groups, dating back to the Late Devonian period. These ancient sharks could grow up to 1.8 meters in length. They were fast and agile predators, characterized by having 5 to 7 gill slits and a short, rounded mouth. Unlike modern sharks, Cladoselache lacked scales and had a streamlined body, allowing for swift movement in the water.

Dunkleosteus is an extinct genus of placoderm fish that existed during the Late Devonian period. The largest species could grow up to 6 meters in length and weigh up to 1 tonne. As a hypercarnivorous apex predator, Dunkleosteus was known for its incredibly strong bite, capable of crushing hard-shelled prey such as ammonites and other armored fish.\nDue to its heavily armored exterior, Dunkleosteus was likely a relatively slow but powerful swimmer. Its massive, bony head shield provided both protection and a powerful leverage system for its jaw, compensating for its lack of true teeth with sharp bony plates.

Acanthostega is an extinct genus of stem-tetrapods and is among the earliest vertebrate animals to have recognizable limbs. It represents an anatomically intermediate form between lobe-finned fishes and fully terrestrial tetrapods. Acanthostega could grow up to 60 cm in length and had eight digits on each hand, linked by webbing.\nDespite having limbs, Acanthostega was primarily an aquatic animal, likely inhabiting shallow, weed-choked swamps. Its limbs were not well adapted for walking on land, indicating that it was still more suited for life in water.

Materpiscis is a genus of placoderm fish that lived near what is now Western Australia. Known from only one specimen, it is unique for containing an unborn embryo preserved inside the mother, along with a mineralized placental feeding structure. This remarkable find makes Materpiscis the oldest known vertebrate to exhibit viviparity, or giving birth to live young.\nMaterpiscis is represented by a single species, Materpiscis attenboroughi, named in honor of Sir David Attenborough, who first highlighted the significance of the Gogo fish sites in his 1979 documentary series "Life on Earth."

Lepidodendron was an extinct, tree-like lycopsid and a dominant component of the Carboniferous coal forest flora. These plants could grow over 30 meters tall, with trunks exceeding 1 meter in diameter. They are believed to have grown rapidly and lived for only 10–15 years. Most species were likely monocarpic, meaning they reproduced just once near the end of their life cycle. By the Mesozoic era, Lepidodendron and its relatives had largely disappeared, likely outcompeted by emerging woody gymnosperms such as conifers, which were better adapted to changing climates and soil conditions.

Sigillaria was an extinct, tree-like lycopsid closely related to Lepidodendron. It could grow up to 30 meters tall and had a relatively short life cycle, characterized by rapid growth and reaching maturity within just a few years. Sigillaria was a prominent member of the Carboniferous coal forests, with its distinctive vertical leaf scars forming a pattern that gives the plant its name.

Calamites was an extinct, tree-like horsetail and a major component of the Carboniferous coal swamps. It could grow up to 30 meters tall and had a hollow, jointed stem structure similar to modern horsetails, but on a much larger scale. Calamites often grew in dense stands along rivers and floodplains, contributing significantly to the formation of coal deposits.

Akmonistion was a shark-like chimaera that lived during the Early Carboniferous. Males had a distinctive anvil-shaped crest instead of a dorsal fin, with barbs on top and a triangular patch of spines located in front of the crest on the head. Females likely resembled the males but may have lacked both the crest and the patch of spines. Akmonistion is sometimes informally called the “ironing board shark” due to the unusual shape of its crest.

Helicoprion was a long-lived genus of shark-like fish known for its unusual spiral arrangement of teeth, often called a "tooth whorl." These teeth were positioned in the lower jaw and may have been used for slicing soft-bodied prey. Helicoprion could reach lengths of 3–4 meters, with some large specimens estimated to grow up to 7.5 meters. Although it resembled a shark, it was more closely related to chimaeras.

Pederpes is the earliest known tetrapod to show clear adaptations for walking on land. Although not classified as an amphibian, it represents a very basal (primitive) member of the tetrapod lineage. Pederpes measured about 1 meter in length and displayed features well suited for terrestrial life, such as forward-facing feet for more effective movement on land. It is currently considered the earliest known fully terrestrial vertebrate.

Proterogyrinus was a reptile-like amphibian and one of the early tetrapods that likely shares ancestry with the first reptiles. It could venture farther from water than most contemporary amphibians and was a top predator in both terrestrial and aquatic environments. Proterogyrinus had strong limbs and a flexible body, allowing it to move efficiently on land while still being an effective swimmer.

Hylonomus is the earliest known unquestionable reptile. It measured about 20 centimeters in length and resembled modern lizards in appearance. With its small, sharp teeth, it likely fed on small invertebrates such as millipedes and early insects. Fossils of Hylonomus have been found inside fossilized tree stumps, suggesting it may have used them for shelter or hunting.

Archaeothyris is the oldest known synapsid—the group of vertebrates that includes modern mammals and their extinct relatives. It resembled a modern-day lizard in appearance, but at around 50 centimeters long, it was one of the largest carnivores in the Carboniferous forests. Archaeothyris had sharp teeth and strong jaws, allowing it to prey on smaller vertebrates and insects.

Pulmonoscorpius was a giant species of extinct scorpion that could grow up to 70 centimeters long. While its exact diet is not known, it likely preyed on smaller arthropods, and its powerful sting may have been capable of killing small early tetrapods. Pulmonoscorpius lived in the humid coal forests of the Carboniferous and is one of the largest scorpions known from the fossil record.

Arthropleura was one of the largest known land invertebrates of all time and had few, if any, natural predators. It could grow up to 2.3 meters in length and about 50 centimeters in width. Like other Carboniferous arthropods, Arthropleura was able to grow so large due to the higher partial pressure of oxygen in Earth\'s atmosphere and the absence of large terrestrial vertebrate predators. This helps explain why similarly sized arthropods did not exist during later periods like the Cretaceous, despite similar oxygen levels.\nContrary to earlier and popular beliefs, Arthropleura was not a predator but an herbivorous arthropod, likely feeding on decaying plant material on the forest floor.

Meganeura was an extinct genus of giant dragonfly-like insects, with a wingspan reaching up to 65 centimeters. Like Arthropleura, they were able to grow so large due to the higher atmospheric oxygen levels and the absence of large aerial predators during the Carboniferous period. Meganeura is one of the largest known flying insects in Earth’s history.

Glossopteris is the largest and best-known genus of seed ferns which grew in the Southern Hemisphere during the Permian period. It was a woody, seed-bearing shrub or tree, some apparently reaching 30 meters tall. They have grown in a very wet soil conditions and outcompeted lycopsids such as Sigillaria and Lepidodendron during the Permian.

Dimetrodon is an extinct synapsid, mammal-like reptile. It could reach 4.6 metres in length and could have weighted up to 250 kilograms. It was probably one of the apex predators, feeding on fish and tetrapods. The sail of Dimetrodon may have been used to stabilize its spine and to heat and cool its body as a form of the thermoregulation.

Titanophoneus or in other words – “titanic murderer” is a carnivorous dinocephalian therapsid from the Middle Permian. The adult skull could reach 80 cm, it also had a heavy long snout and its total body length was about 2.9 meters.
Estemmenosuchus (meaning “crowned crocodile” in Greek) was a large omnivorous therapsid. It lived during the Middle Permian and could grow up to 3 meters long.
Gorgonops were the dominant predators of their day and lived during the Late Permian. They could grow up to 3 meters long. They had two enlarged canine teeth, which could grow up to 12 cm in length.

The cynodonts (“dog teeth”) are therapsids that first appeared in the Late Permian. This group includes modern mammals (including humans) as well as their extinct ancestors and close relatives. Non-mammalian cynodonts spread throughout Southern Gondwana and had many mammalian skeletal features. All cynodonts probably laid eggs (like the modern day platypus) and had some form of the warm-blooded metabolism, because many of them had fur.

Bennettitales were plants resembling the flowering plants, because of their flower-like reproductive structures. Although similar, they are more closely related to the modern cycads, ginkgo and conifers than angiosperms. However, this clade is polyphyletic, so there is a possibility, that some Bennettitales form a clade with Angiosperms.

Morganucodon was an early mammaliaform cynodont that lived during the Late Triassic. It was a small nocturnal animal with a body length reaching up to 10 cm – an example specimen of the nocturnal bottleneck effect.

Lystrosaurus was a herbivorous genus of Late Permian and Early Triassic therapsids, which size was similar to the pig. At least one Lystrosaurus specie survived the Permian-Triassic mass extinction and in the absence of predators and herbivorous competitors it became the most common terrestrial vertebrate during the Early Triassic. At one time, almost 90% of the land vertebrates belonged to this genus!

Pterosaurs were flying reptiles, which lived since the Late Triassic until the end of the Cretaceous. They were the earliest vertebrates to have evolved powered flight. Pterosauria were not “flying dinosaurs”, they actually do not belong to the Dinosauria clade.

Plesiosauria was a group of marine reptiles, which lived throughout Mesozoic era. They had a flat body and a short tail. They breathed atmospheric air and bore live young; there are indicators that they were warm-blooded.

Ichthyosaurs were large marine reptiles which thrived during much of the Mesozoic. They were among the top aquatic predators until the Late Jurassic and Cretaceous, when they were outcompeted by the newly emerged plesiosaurs.

Mystriosuchus was a crocodile-like reptile that lived in the Late Triassic. It grew up to 4 metres long, cranial morphology is suggestive of a primarily fish eating diet, having long jaws like those of the modern gharials.

Plateosaurus was a basal sauropodomorph dinosaur (group which will later include some of the largest animals on Earth like Diplodocus, Argentinosaurus etc.). Fully grown individuals were between 5 and 10 metres long and weighted 600–4000 kilograms. Commonly they lived at least from 12 to 20 years.
Desmatosuchus is an extinct genus of archosaurs that could grow up to 4.5 meters in length. They were widespread and it is suggested, that they could have been omnivorous or even insectivorous.
Longisquama is a genus of extinct reptile, which probably has no bearing on the origin of birds. The structures on its back are actually more like scales than feathers.
Sharovipteryx is one of the earliest known gliding reptiles, known only from a single fossil.

Tanystropheus was a 6 metre long reptile with an extremely elongated neck, which measured 3 metres long. Even it looks like a dinosaur, it belongs to another reptile group – protosauria, and is not related to similarly looking sauropods. It was probably aquatic or semi-aquatic and is most often considered to eat fish.

Archaeopteryx is a genus of the bird-like dinosaurs, which shows a transition between the non-avian feathered dinosaurs and the modern birds. Largest individuals possibly were looking like ravens, but in addition they also had jaws with sharp teeth, three clawed fingers on each wing and a long bony tail.

Allosaurus was a large bipedal predator, which could grow up to 8.5 m in length and was at the top of the food chain. Their potential prey included ornithopods, stegosaurids, and sauropods. Some paleontologists interpret Allosaurus as having had cooperative social behavior, and hunting in packs, while others believe individuals may have been aggressive toward each other, and that congregations of this genus are the result of lone individuals feeding on the same carcasses. It may have attacked large prey by ambush, using its upper jaw like a hatchet.

Mamenchisaurus was a sauropod dinosaur genus, which included several species known for their remarkably long necks which made up half of their total body length. The largest species may have reached 35 m in length and possibly weighed 50 to 75 tons.

Stegosaurus is a genus of the armoured dinosaurs. They were large, heavily built herbivorous animals. Their large body plates were probably used for thermoregulatory functions.\nThe first specimen was collected during the “Bone Wars” – famous fossil rivalry between Edward Drinker Cope and Othniel Charles Marsh.
Epidexipteryx was a small bird-like dinosaur, representing the earliest known example of the ornamental feathers in the fossil record.

Dilophosaurus was among the largest predators of its time and had a pair of rounded crests on its skull. It measured about 7 meters long and weighed about 400 kilograms. This dinosaur was inaccurately featured in the Jurassic Park movie - it had no frills, it definitely did not spit poison and was much bigger.

Dimorphodon was a medium-sized pterosaur, which probably inhabited coastal regions. It was a rather poor flyer because of the short wings, and it probably relied on frantic short flights in the same manner as modern fowls and woodpeckers.
Epidendrosaurus was a sparrow-size feathered avialan dinosaur, which probably lived on trees feeding on insects.

Liopleurodon is a genus of large, carnivorous marine reptile belonging to the Plesiosauria group. Their fossils have been found mainly in England and France. Liopleurodon was a powerful swimmer and usually could grow up to 5-7 metres.

Kentrosaurus is a genus of stegosaurian dinosaur from the Late Jurassic of Tanzania. It measured around 4.5 metres in length and weighed about one tonne. Kentrosaurus was a herbivore and probably lived in a predator-heavy environment because of its heavy armouring.

Tyrannosaurus is probably the most famous dinosaur, well known from such TV movies like “Jurassic Park”, “Lost World” etc. Also it is one of the most well-represented large dinosaurs. Tyrannosaurus lived throughout what is now Western North America. The most complete specimen measures up to 12.3 meters in length and up to 3.7 meters in height.\nWhile there is no direct evidence for Tyrannosaurus having feathers, many scientists now consider that it likely had feathers on at least some parts of its body, due to their presence in related species. Below is an artistic interpretation of the T. rex.

Velociraptor was a bipedal, feathered carnivore with a long tail and enlarged sickle-shaped claw on each hind foot. Like Tyrannosaurus, it is also one of the most familiar dinosaurs due to its prominent role in the “Jurassic Park” movie. In real life, however, Velociraptor was roughly the size of a turkey, considerably smaller than the approximately 2 m tall reptiles seen in the films. Also, real Velociraptors were feathered and warm blooded.

Spinosaurus was among the largest of all known carnivorous dinosaurs, possibly larger than Tyrannosaurus. It could grow up to 14.3 metres long and could weigh around 20 tonnes. It is known to have eaten fish, and most scientists believe that it hunted both terrestrial and aquatic prey. They lived both on land and in the water as modern crocodiles do.
Pachycephalosaurus was a bipedal herbivore with an extremely thick skull roof. Also it was one of the last living non-avian dinosaurs before the Cretaceous-Paleogene extinction.

Triceratops was a herbivorous dinosaur and one of the last known non-avian dinosaurs. It is estimated, that Triceratops could grow up to 9 meters in length, 3 meters in height and could weigh about 12 tonnes.

Ankylosaurus was a genus of the armored dinosaurs which was among the last of the surviving non-avian dinosaurs. Large individuals measured up to 6.25 meters in length, 1.7 meters in height and weighed 6 tonnes. Newly discovered fossils revealed, that some of the Ankylosaurus species had antipredator colorations, which evidence a high predator pressure towards the end of the Cretaceous.

Mosasaurus is an extinct carnivorous aquatic lizard which could grow up to 17 meters in length. It is believed, that it lived close to the ocean surface, where it preyed on fish, turtles, ammonites, smaller mosasaurs, birds, pterosaurs and plesiosaurs.

Ammonites is an extinct group of marine mollusc animals. They are excellent index fossils and appeared in the Devonian. They are mentioned here, because they are the most famous mollusc group extinct in the Cretaceous-Paleogene event.

Therizinosaurus cheloniformis was a large and unique dinosaur. At 10 meters in length and 5 tons in weight, they also had gigantic claws, longest known from any animal, sometimes reaching even 70 centimeters in length.
Tsintaosaurus had a characteristic “duck bill” snout and a battery of powerful teeth which were used to chew vegetation. It was about 10 meters long and 3.6 meters tall.

Deinocheirus was an unusual dinosaur, largest growing up to 11 meters long, and weighing 6.4 tonnes. It had a pair of large arms and probably was omnivorous. It used those long claws for digging and gathering plants. It is thought, that Deinocherus was a slow animal.

Quetzalcoatlus was a very large pterosaur and one of the largest known flying animals of all time. Its name comes from the Mesoamerican feathered serpent god, Quetzalcoatl. Its wingspan reached 10–11 meters and whole individual was at least 3 meters tall.

Giganotosaurus was a large dinosaur, similar or even larger than Tyrannosaurus. It lived in what is now Argentina. Like Tyrannosaurus, it had a metabolism intermediate between that of mammals and reptiles, and was able to sustain a stable body temperature.
Linhenykus is the only known a non-avian dinosaur to have a single digit. It was small-bodied and lived in what is now Mongolia. Although it looks like an ostrich, it is not related to them.

Sarcosuchus is an extinct genus of crocodyliform and distant relative of living crocodylians. It is one of the largest crocodile–like reptiles and it lived in what is now Africa and South America. It was almost twice as long (up to 11–12 m) as the modern saltwater crocodile and weighed up to 8 tonnes. They lived in freshwater environment and probably hunted both fish and terrestrial prey (like the Nile crocodiles do).

Microraptor was a genus of small, four-winged paravian dinosaurs. Their well-preserved fossils provide important evidence about the evolutionary relationship between birds and dinosaurs. It was among the most abundant non-avialan dinosaurs in its ecosystem. Adult specimens estimated up to 77 centimeters long and weighed up to 1 kilogram. Microraptor was an opportunistic predator, which hunted on small mammals, other bird-like dinosaurs and fish.
Titanoboa is the largest known snake, which could reach 13 meters in length and weigh up to 1.2 tonnes. It mostly fed on fish and lived in the Paleocenian tropics.

Gastornis were very large birds that lived during the Late Paleocene and Eocene. They could grow up to 2 metres in height and have traditionally been considered to be predators of small mammals. However, several lines of evidence, including the lack of hooked claws in known Gastornis footprints and studies of their beak structure have caused scientists to reinterpret these birds as herbivores that probably fed on tough plant material and seeds.

Basilosaurus is a genus of the early whales that lived in the Late Eocene. Unlike modern whales, Basilosaurus was an apex predator.\nBelow you can see the currently known transitional whale evolution forms.

Paraceratherium is an extinct genus of hornless rhinoceros and one of the largest terrestrial mammals that has ever existed. Its height was about 4.8 metres, and the length about 7.4 metres, and weight is estimated to have been 15 to 20 tonnes.

Daeodon is an extinct genus of artiodactyl (elks, boars, bisons etc. are artiodactyls too) that inhabited North America during the Late Oligocene and Early Miocene epochs. They were around 1.8 m tall at the shoulders and had skulls about 90 cm long.

Pyrotherium is an extinct mammal genus related to the modern ungulates (like pigs, cattle, deers), that lived in Argentina during the Early Oligocene. They could weigh up to 3500 kg and were about 1.5 metres tall.
Archaeotherium is an extinct animal related to the pigs, which lived in the modern North America. It was about 1.2 metres tall and weighed around 270 kg.

Arsinoitherium is an extinct mammal related to the modern elephants. They were rhinoceros-like herbivores that lived in the northern Africa, in areas of the tropical rainforest and at the margin of the mangrove swamps. Adult species stood around 1.75 meters tall.

Argentavis is among the largest flying birds ever to exist, having an estimated wing span of 5–6 meters, a height of 1.5–2 meters and a mass of approximately 70 kilograms. It probably preferred to scavenge for carrion.

Ardipithecus might be one of the earliest ancestors of humans after they diverged from the main ape lineage, although it is still a matter of debate. It was very similar to chimpanzees and lived in the territory of the modern Ethiopia. Ardipithecus had a small brain, measuring between 300 and 350 cm3. This is slightly smaller than a modern chimpanzee brain and roughly 20% the size of the modern human brain. Nevertheless, it is in some ways unlike chimpanzees, suggesting that the common ancestor differs from the modern chimpanzee. After the chimpanzee and human lineages diverged, both underwent substantial evolutionary change. Chimp feet are specialized for grasping trees; Ardipithecus feet are better suited for walking.

Carcharodon megalodon also known as megalodon is an extinct species of shark which lived almost until the end of the Neogene. It was one of the largest and most powerful predators in vertebrate history, reaching 18 metres in length. It is known, that they preyed on whales and fish. They extinct probably because of the multiple reasons, including the oceanic cooling, sea level drops and the decline in food supply.

Livyatan is an extinct whale, similar in size to the modern sperm whale. It reached almost 18 meters in length and had powerful functional teeth in both of its jaws. It was an apex predator along with the giant megalodon. Its extinction was likely caused by a cooling event at the end of the Miocene which resulted in a drop in food populations. The formations where the whale has been found have also preserved a large assemblage of marine life, such as sharks and marine mammals.

Titanis walleri is a large extinct flightless carnivorous bird, which lived in the North America. It was about 2.5 meters tall and weighed approximately 150 kilograms. It is one of the famous terror birds, which were dominant predators in the early Cenozoic and Middle Cenozoic era.

Deinotherium was a large prehistoric relative of the modern-day elephants. They differed only by a shorter trunk, and it had downward curling tusks attached to the lower jaw. They could grow up to 4 meters tall and weigh about 12 tonnes.
Platybelodon was a large herbivorous mammal related to the elephants. They lived in Asia and the Caucascus.

Stegotetrabelodon is an extinct primitive elephant with four tusks instead of two. They lived in Africa and were very similar to the modern elephants. Below is an artist interpretation, how it really could look like.

Mammoths were large mammals, close elephant relatives covered by the long hair. Most of the mammoths were as large as the modern Asian elephants and lived in the northern hemisphere where colder climate was prevalent.
They fed on trees and shrubs. Mammoths vanished from Africa about 3–4 million years ago, from Europe and American mainland – about 10,000 years ago and some small populations survived almost until the recent days. The last known population lived in Wrangel island, until it died 3750 years ago.
The main cause of their extinction was the warming climate that occurred 12,000 years ago, accompanied by a glacial retreat, rising sea levels and diminishing of the plain tundra by the forests.
Currently, there are two separate projects in Japan and South Korea working towards recreating mammoth specimens from the DNA extracted from the frozen mammoths. Also, there is an ongoing project in the northeastern part of Russia called Pleistocene Park, where the russian scientist S. Zimov and his team are trying to prepare pasture for the possibly cloned mammoths. I really recommend watching a VICE documentary called “The Crazy Solution For Keeping The Melting Arctic Frozen”.

Coelodonta is an extinct genus of woolly rhinoceros that lived in Eurasia almost until the recent days. Many species of Pleistocene megafauna, like woolly rhinoceros, became extinct around the same period. Human hunting is often cited as the possible cause of their extinction. Other extinction theories are associated with the climate change and the receding ice age. The last woolly rhinoceros population lived in Western Siberia about 10,000 years ago.

Megatherium was a genus of elephant-size ground sloths, that lived in South America. It weighed around 4 tonnes and measured up to 6 meters in length. It was adapted to temperate, arid or semi-arid open habitats. It fed on leaves such as yuccas, agaves and grasses. They died about 10,000 years ago because of the fragmentation of their habitats.

Smilodon is the best known as the saber tooth cat. It lived in the Americas almost until the recent days and could weigh almost 400 kilograms and grow up to 120 cm tall. They hunted large herbivores such as bisons and camels. They extinct together with the other large herbivores, because prey became smaller and more agile.

Latimeria (or Coelacanth) is the oldest known living lobe-finned fish, known as the living fossil. They may live as long as 80 to 100 years and live as deep as 700 m below sea level. They feed on squids, small sharks and other fish. Scientists suspect one reason this fish has been so successful is that the specimens are able to slow down their metabolism at will. They live near the Sodwana Bay, South Africa.

The Xiphosura, which includes the horseshoe crabs is the group, that hardly changed in millions of years and are considered to be the living fossils. They are related with another dominant Paleozoic arthropod group – trilobites. Their blood is very important for the modern medicine, because it is used for the detection of the bacterial endotoxins.

Ginkgo is the only living species of the ancient plant division Ginkgophyta. It is found in fossils dating back 270 million years. Native to China, the tree is widely cultivated and is used in traditional medicine and as a source of food.

Welwitschia is one of the three genus of the ancient plant division Gnetophyta. It grows in the Namib desert and is known as a living fossil. Many current individuals are over 1000 years old and some may be more than 2000 years old. Welwitschia produces a single pair of foliage leaves. Gnetophyta plants are relatives of the modern flowering plants.

Tuatara are reptiles endemic to New Zealand and the only alive specimens of the ancient reptile group – Rhynchocephalia, which flourished around 200 million years ago. They measure up to 80 cm and weigh up to 1.3 kg. They are terrestrial and nocturnal and thrive in much lower temperatures than those tolerated by most reptiles and hibernate during winter.\nNow they are extremely endangered because of the introduced rats and the habitat loss.

Human or Homo sapiens is the most successful large vertebrate species to ever roam the Earth. The estimated human population by the 2017 is around 7.5 billion and humans occupy most of the natural niches except the deep oceans, salt lakes, deep caves and Antarctica (although there are some specimens reported to live there, at least seasonally). It is currently deemed of “least concern” on the Red List of endangered species by the IUCN.\nTraditionally, there are two competing views of paleoanthropology about the origin of the H. sapiens: the recent African origin and the multiregional origin. More accepted single origin theory states, that modern humans appeared in East Africa and later migrated up north, when the glaciers retreated. They overwhelmed northern living H. neanderthalensis, which were already losing their genetic diversity and later migrated all around the world, by killing and destroying most of the natural habitats and animal species on their way. Later it became an apex, opportunistic predator, however different human populations specialized in different kind of food, for example: Japanese are regarded as the most ferocious marine predators, killing thousands of whales, dolphins, sharks and other sea animals each year; Chinese are known for their passion of killing rhinoceros, elephants and other horned animals, they even recently wiped out the Northern White Rhinoceros species in Africa, great job! European populations have depleted their natural resources long time ago, so they usually use other populations to bring them food and are best known for their manipulative skills and so on.\nThe human creating this application is about 1.83 meters long and weights about 69 kilograms, and is alive because of the photosynthesis.

The dodo is an extinct flightless bird that was endemic to the island of Mauritius, east of Madagascar in the Indian Ocean. It was about 1 metre tall and may have weighed up to 17 kg and is related to the pigeons. The dodo was historically been considered fat and clumsy, but it was well-adapted for its ecosystem. It used gizzard stones to help digest their food (mainly fruits).\nThe first recorded mention of the dodo was by Dutch sailors in 1598. In the following years, the bird was hunted by sailors and invasive species, while its habitat was being destroyed. The last widely accepted sighting of a dodo was in 1662. The extinction of the dodo within less than a century of its discovery called attention to the previously unrecognized problem of human involvement in the disappearance of entire species.

Megalania is an extinct giant lizard and it was a part of a megafauna that inhabited southern Australia during the Pleistocene. The youngest fossil remains date around 50,000 years ago. The first aboriginal settlers of Australia might have encountered them and been a factor in their extinction. Largest individuals could grow up to 7 m long with a maximum weight of approximately 600–620 kg. It fed mostly upon medium to large sized animals and had a jaw full of serrated blade-like teeth.
